topic.title: Configure Kerberos For Windows Clients
topic.shortdesc: You can configure Microsoft Windows client applications to connect to a Greenplum Database system that is configured to authenticate with Kerberos.

body.p: For information about configuring Greenplum Database with Kerberos authentication, see .

When a Greenplum Database system is configured to authenticate with Kerberos, the Greenplum Database client utilities gpload and psql authenticate with Kerberos directly, not with Microsoft Active Directory. You install and configure Kerberos on your Microsoft Windows system to connect to Greenplum Database with the Greenplum Database Windows client utilities.
This section contains the following information.

section.title: Configuring Kerberos on a Windows System
section.p: To use Kerberos authentication with the Greenplum Database clients on a Windows system, you manage Kerberos tickets with the Kerberos kinit utility. For Windows, the MIT Kerberos for Windows 4.0.1 (for krb5) contains the kinit utility and is available at http://web.mit.edu/kerberos/dist/index.html.
section.note: The automatic start up of the Kerberos service is not enabled. The service cannot be used to authenticate with Greenplum Database.
section.p: To configure a Windows system for Kerberos, requires these steps.

ul.li:
Configuring a Kerberos configuration file.
Create a copy of the Kerberos configuration file /etc/krb5.conf from the Greenplum Database master and place it in default Kerberos location on the Windows system C:\ProgramData\MIT\Kerberos5\krb5.ini. In the file section [libdefaults], remove the Location of the Kerberos kicket cache default_ccache_name.

Specifying a Kerberos ticket with the Kerberos command kinit.
On the Windows system, the environment variable KRB5CCNAME specifies the location of the Kerberos ticket (the keytab file). The value for environment variable is a file not a directory, and should be unique for each login on the Greenplum Database. To create a keytab file, see

section.p: This is an example configuration file with default_ccache_name removed. Also, the section [logging] is removed.

When specifying a Kerberos ticket with KRB5CCNAME, you can specify the value in either a local user environment or within a session. These commands set KRB5CCNAME, runs kinit, and runs the batch file to set the environment variables for the Greenplum Database clients.

section.title: Creating a Kerberos Keytab File
section.p:
You can create and use a Kerberos keytab file to avoid entering a password at the command line or the listing a password in a script file when connecting to a Greenplum Database system. You can create a keyab file with these utilities.
Windows Kerberos utility ktpass
Java JRE keytab utility ktab
If you use AES256-CTS-HMAC-SHA1-96 encryption, you need download and install the Java extension Java Cryptography Extension (JCE) Unlimited Strength Jurisdiction Policy Files for JDK/JRE from Oracle.

You run the ktpass utility as an AD Domain Administrator. The utility expects a user account to have a Service Principal Name (SPN) defined as an AD user attribute. However, the SPN does not appear to be required. You can specify the SPN as a parameter to ktpass and ignore the warning that it cannot be set.
The Java JRE ktab utility does not require an AD Domain Administrator and does not require an SPN.
section.note: When you enter the password to create the keytab file, the password is visible on screen.
section.p: This example runs the ktpass utility to create the ketyab dev1.keytab. This command creates a keytab despite the warning message Unable to set SPN mapping data.
section.codeblock: ktpass -out dev1.keytab -princ dev1@EXAMPLE.LOCAL -mapUser dev1 -pass your_password -crypto all -ptype KRB5_NT_PRINCIPAL
section.p: This example runs the Java ktab.exe with the -a option to create a keytab file.
section.codeblock: C:\Users\dev1>"\Program Files\Java\jre1.8.0_77\bin"\ktab -a dev1 Password for dev1@EXAMPLE.LOCAL:your_password Done! Service key for dev1 is saved in C:\Users\dev1\krb5.keytab
section.p: This example runs the Java ktab.exe with the -l -e -t options to list the keytab name and entries.
section.codeblock: C:\Users\dev1>"\Program Files\Java\jre1.8.0_77\bin"\ktab -l -e -t Keytab name: C:\Users\dev1\krb5.keytab KVNO Timestamp Principal ---- -------------- ------------------------------------------------------ 4 13/04/16 19:14 dev1@EXAMPLE.LOCAL (18:AES256 CTS mode with HMAC SHA1-96) 4 13/04/16 19:14 dev1@EXAMPLE.LOCAL (17:AES128 CTS mode with HMAC SHA1-96) 4 13/04/16 19:14 dev1@EXAMPLE.LOCAL (16:DES3 CBC mode with SHA1-KD) 4 13/04/16 19:14 dev1@EXAMPLE.LOCAL (23:RC4 with HMAC)
section.p:
You can use the keytab with the following Kerberos kinit command to obtain and cache Kerberos ticket-granting tickets.
If you used ktpass to create the keytab.kinit -kt dev1.keytab dev1
If you used ktab to create the keytab.kinit -kt %USERPROFILE%\krb5.keytab dev1

section.title: Example of Running the psql Utility
section.p: After installing and configuring Kerberos and the Kerberos ticket on a Windows system, you can run the Greenplum Database command line client psql.
If you get warnings indicating that the Console code page differs from Windows code page, you can run the Windows utility chcp to change the code page. This is an example of the warning and fix.
section.codeblock:
psql -h prod1.example.local warehouse psql (8.2.15) WARNING: Console code page (850) differs from Windows code page (1252) 8-bit characters might not work correctly. See psql reference page "Notes for Windows users" for details. Type "help" for help.
warehouse=# \q
chcp 1252 Active code page: 1252
psql -h prod1.example.local warehouse psql (8.2.15) Type "help" for help.

section.title: Example gpload YAML File
section.p: This is an example of the user dev1 logged onto a Windows desktop with the AD domain.
In the example, the USER: line from the test.yaml control file has been removed.
section.codeblock:
--- VERSION: 1.0.0.1 DATABASE: warehouse HOST: prod1.example.local PORT: 5432
GPLOAD: INPUT: - SOURCE: PORT_RANGE: [18080,18080] FILE: - /Users/dev1/Downloads/test.csv - FORMAT: csv - DELIMITER: ',' - QUOTE: '"' - ERROR_LIMIT: 25 - ERROR_TABLE: public.test_errors OUTPUT: - TABLE: public.test - MODE: INSERT
section.p: These commands run kinit and then gpload with the test.yaml file and displays successful gpload output.
section.codeblock:
kinit -kt %USERPROFILE%\krb5.keytab dev1
gpload.py -f test.yaml 2016-04-10 16:54:12|INFO|gpload session started 2016-04-10 16:54:12 2016-04-10 16:54:12|INFO|started gpfdist -p 18080 -P 18080 -f "/Users/dev1/Downloads/test.csv" -t 30 2016-04-10 16:54:13|INFO|running time: 0.23 seconds 2016-04-10 16:54:13|INFO|rows Inserted = 3 2016-04-10 16:54:13|INFO|rows Updated = 0 2016-04-10 16:54:13|INFO|data formatting errors = 0 2016-04-10 16:54:13|INFO|gpload succeeded

ul.li:
This message indicates that Kerberos cannot find your cache file:Credentials cache I/O operation failed XXX (Kerberos error 193) krb5_cc_default() failed
To ensure that Kerberos can find the file, set the environment variable KRB5CCNAME and run kinit.Kerberos cannot find your cache file.set KRB5CCNAME=%USERPROFILE%\krb5cache kinit

This kinit message indicates that the kinit -k -t command could not find the keytab.kinit: Generic preauthentication failure while getting initial credentials
Confirm that the full path and filename for the Kerberos keytab file is correct.

topic.title: Windows Client Applications that use Active Directory

body.p: You can configure a Microsoft Windows user with a Microsoft Active Directory (AD) account for single sign-on to a Greenplum Database system that is configured to authenticate the user login with Kerberos.
The process requires the configuration of the Windows AD user account to support logging in with Kerberos authentication.

With AD single sign-on, a Windows user can use Active Directory credentials with a Windows client application to log into a Greenplum Database system. For example, a Windows user can use Active Directory credentials with PGadmin III to access a Greenplum Database system. Also, for Windows applications that use ODBC, the ODBC driver can use Active Directory credentials to connect to a Greenplum Databases system.
body.note: Greenplum Database clients that run on Windows, such as gpload, connect with Greenplum Database directly and do not use Active Directory. See .
body.p: This section describes how to use Microsoft Active Directory with Greenplum Database that is configured to authenticate a user login with Kerberos.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: These items are required enable AD single sign-on to a Greenplum Database system.

ul.li: The Greenplum Database system must be configured to support for Kerberos authentication. For information about configuring Greenplum Database with Kerberos authentication, see .

You must know the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) of the Greenplum Database master host. Also, the Greenplum Database master host name must have a domain portion. If the system does do not have a domain, you must configure the system to use a domain.
This Linux hostname command displays the FQDN.hostname --fqdn

You must confirm that the Greenplum Database system has the same date and time as the Active Directory domain. For example, you could set the Greenplum Database system NTP time source to be an AD Domain Controller, or configure the master host to use the same external time source as the AD Domain Controller.

To support single sign-on, you configure an AD user account as a Managed Service Account in AD. These are requirements for Kerboros authentication.
Add the Service Principal Name (SPN) attribute to the user account information because the Kerberos utilities require the information during Kerberos authentication.
Provide the account login details in a Kerberos keytab file for Greenplum database unattended startups. Setting the SPN and creating the keytab requires AD administrative permissions.

section.title: Configuring Active Directory
section.p: The AD naming convention should support multiple Greenplum Database systems. In this example, we create a new AD Managed Service Account svcPostresProd1 for our prod1 Greenplum Database system master host.
The Active Directory domain is example.local. The fully qualified domain name for the Greenplum Database master host is prod1.example.local.
Add the SPN postgres/prod1.example.local to this account. Service accounts for other Greenplum Database systems will all be in the form postgres/fully.qualified.hostname.

In this example, the AD password is set to never expire and cannot be changed by the user. The AD account password is only used when creating the Kerberos keytab file. There is no requirement to provide it to a database administrator.

An AD administrator must add the Service Principal Name (SPN) attribute to the account from the command line with the Windows setspn command. This example command set the SPN attribute value to postgres/prod1.example.local for the AD user svcPostgresProd1:
You can see the SPN if Advanced Features are set in the Active Directory Users and Computers view. Find servicePrincipalName in the Attribute Editor tab and edit it if you need to make changes.

body.section:
Creating a Kerberos Keytab FileTo authenticate with Greenplum Database that uses Kerberos authentication requires a Kerberos keytab file.
You can select a specific cryptography method if your security requirements require it, but in the absence of that, it is best to get it to work first and then remove any cryptography methods you do not want.
As an AD Domain Administrator, you can list the types of encryption that your AD domain controller supports with this ktpass command:ktpass /?
As an AD Domain Administrator, you can run the ktpass command to create a keytab file. This example command creates the file svcPostgresProd1.keytab with this information: ServicePrincipalName (SPN): postgres/prod1.example.local@EXAMPLE.LOCAL AD user: svcPostgresProd1 Encryption methods: ALL available on AD Principal Type: KRB5_NT_PRINCIPAL ktpass -out svcPostgresProd1.keytab -princ postgres/prod1.example.local@EXAMPLE.LOCAL -mapUser svcPostgresProd1 -pass your_password -crypto all -ptype KRB5_NT_PRINCIPALThe AD domain @EXAMPLE.LOCAL is appended to the SPN.
You copy the keytab file svcPostgresProd1.keytab to the Greenplum Database master host.
As an alternative to running ktpass as an AD Domain Administrator, you can run the Java ktab.exe utility to generate a keytab file if you have the Java JRE installed on your desktop. When you enter the password using either ktpass or ktab.exe, the password will be visible on the screen as a command ling argument.
This example ktab.exe command creates the keyab file svcPostgresProd1.keytab."c:\Program Files\Java\jre1.8.0_77\bin\ktab.exe" -a svcPostgresprod1 -k svcPostgresProd1.keytab Password for svcPostgresprod1@EXAMPLE.LOCAL:your_password Done! Service key for svcPostgresprod1 is saved in svcPostgresProd1.keytabIf you use AES256-CTS-HMAC-SHA1-96 encryption, requires download and install the Java extension Java Cryptography Extension (JCE) Unlimited Strength Jurisdiction Policy Files for JDK/JRE from Oracle.

section.title: Configuring Greenplum Database
section.p: These instructions assume that the Kerberos workstation utilities krb5-workstation are installed on the Greenplum Database master host.
Update /etc/krb5.conf with the AD domain name details and the location of an AD domain controller. This is an example configuration file.
section.codeblock:
[logging] default = FILE:/var/log/krb5libs.log kdc = FILE:/var/log/krb5kdc.log admin_server = FILE:/var/log/kadmind.log
[libdefaults] default_realm = EXAMPLE.LOCAL dns_lookup_realm = false dns_lookup_kdc = false ticket_lifetime = 24h renew_lifetime = 7d forwardable = true
[realms] EMEA.LOCAL = { kdc = bocdc.example.local admin_server = bocdc.example.local }
[domain_realm] .example.local = EXAMPLE.LOCAL example.com = EXAMPLE.LOCAL
section.p: Copy the Kerberos keytab file that contains the AD user information to the Greenplum Database master directory. This example copies svcPostgresProd1.keytab that was created in .

Add this line as the last line in the Greenplum Database pg_hba.conf file. This line configures Greenplum Database authentication to use Active Directory for authentication for a connection attempt that is not matched by a previous pg_hba.conf line.

Update the Greenplum Database postgresql.conf file with the location details for the keytab file and the principal name to use. The fully qualified hostname and the default realm from /etc/krb5.conf forms the full service principal name.
Create a database role for the AD user. This example logs into default database and runs the CREATE ROLE command. The user dev1 is the user specified when creating the keytab file in .
section.codeblock: psql # CREATE ROLE dev1 WITH LOGIN superuser;
section.p: Restart the Greenplum Database to use the updated the authentication information.
section.note: The Greenplum Database libraries might conflict with the Kerberos workstation utilities such as kinit. If you are using these utilities on the Greenplum Database master, you can either run a gpadmin shell that does not source the $GPHOME/greenplum_path.sh script, or unset the LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable similar to this example:unset LD_LIBRARY_PATH kinit source $GPHOME/greenplum_path.sh
section.p: Confirm Greenplum Database access with Kerberos authentication. In this example, the kinit command obtains and caches an initial ticket-granting ticket for the user dev1 before logging into the database.

section.title: Single Sign-On Examples
section.p: These single sign-on examples that use AD and Kerberos assume that the AD user dev1 configured for single sign-on is logged into the Windows desktop.

This example connects to Greenplum Database from pgAdmin III with single sign-on. You must specify the fully qualified hostname as the Host and the Windows user ID (dev1) as the Username when completing the New Server Registration dialog box.
Also,when you reconnect to the database, pgAdmin III prompts for a password. When prompted, leave the field blank and click OK.
This example configures Aginity Workbench for Pivotal Greenplum. When using single sign-on, you enable Use Integrated Security.

This example configures a Postgres psqlodbc driver as an ODBC source. When setting up the ODBC source, do not enter a User Name or Password. This DSN can then be used by applications as an ODBC data source.
You can use the DSN testdata with an R client. This example configures R to access the DSN.
section.codeblock: library("RODBC") conn <- odbcDriverConnect("testdata") sql <- "select * from public.data1" my_data <- sqlQuery(conn,sql) print(my_data)

ul.li:
Kerberos tickets contain a version number that must match the version number for Active Directory.
To display the version number in your keytab file, use the klist -ket command. For example:klist -ket svcPostgresProd1.keytab
To get the corresponding value from AD domain controller, run this command as an AD Administrator:kvno postgres/prod1.example.local@EXAMPLE.LOCAL

This login error can occur when there is a mismatch between the Widows ID and the Greenplum database user role ID. This log file entry shows the login error. A user dev22 is attempting to login from a Windows desktop where the user is logged in as a different Windows user.2016-03-29 14:30:54.041151 PDT,"dev22","gpadmin",p15370,th2040321824, "172.28.9.181","49283",2016-03-29 14:30:53 PDT,1917,con32,,seg-1,,,x1917,sx1, "FATAL","28000","authentication failed for user ""dev22"": valid until timestamp expired",,,,,,,0,,"auth.c",628,
The error can also occur when the user can be authenticated, but does not have a Greenplum database user role.
Ensure that the user is using the correct Windows ID and that a Greenplum Database user role is configured for the user ID.

li.p: This error can occur when the Kerberos keytab does not contain a matching cryptographic type to a client attempting to connect. psql -h 'hostname' template1 psql: GSSAPI continuation error: Unspecified GSS failure. Minor code may provide more information GSSAPI continuation error: Key version is not available
The resolution is to add the additional encryption types to the keytab using ktutil or recreating the postgres keytab with all crypto systems from AD.
